translation.en: ♪ I'm living in two worlds ♪
♪ Dividing my time ♪
♪ Unhappy in your world… ♪
[grunts]
Hit me where it hurts!
[mouse click]
♪ When I'm in your world ♪
♪ I just pretend ♪
♪ That I'm really happy ♪
♪ Though I don't fit in… ♪
-[metallic crunch] -[grunts]
Hit me where it hurts!
-[indistinct press chatter] -[cameras clicking]
♪ I'm living in two worlds ♪
♪ Where do I belong… ♪
[grunts]
Hit me where it hurts!
[cameras clicking]
♪ Unhappy in your world ♪
♪ And lonesome in mine ♪
♪ I'm living in two worlds ♪
[thud]
♪ Dividing my time ♪
[groans] Hit me where it hurts!
♪ Unhappy in your world ♪
♪ And lonesome in mine ♪
[woman 1] We're behind, so we need to get you in hair and makeup
-and on set ASAP. -Remember, we have that Facetime session
with the new director of the Sony franchise.
You have a phone interview with In Touch Weekly at 1:00.
They're doing the first scene now with the stand-in.
We're gonna do a table read of all the re-writes later at lunch.
Don't worry, we'll get you that kale Caesar, no croutons.
And we need to do a face cast.
We need to book in some time for a photo shoot.
And I'll put that on your schedule.
There's a doctor coming to check the rash you got from the prosthetic you wore,
and to give you a B12 shot.
You need somebody to run lines with you. Do we have any spare humans?
But we do need to get you into hair and makeup.
We really need you to go into hair and makeup right now, Miss Black.
Fuck you, fuck you and fuck you!
Fuck my life!
[door slams]
[bell rings]
[woman] Okay, hold the work.
We're gonna do a first team rehearsal with the stand-in.
All right. Everybody, set.
Okay, action.
I have the ring right here.
I took it off Grandma's finger while she was dying.
Well, almost dying.
My bitch sister is at a party. She doesn't even know I have it.
She's never gonna get her hands on it.
[fake scream]
That hit me where it hurts.
[woman] Okay, that's a cut on rehearsal!
[bell rings]
[woman] Okay, guys, that was great. Looks great.
Andy, could you try and take that pull back, like, 10%?
A little bit slower. Thank you.
-Excuse me, Barbara. -Yeah?
I know Candy, and she's gonna want to stop at the armchair,
so maybe we could move the mark over.
Yeah, sure. Thanks, Paula. I'll tell Cameron.
Okay, thank you.
[Barbara] Have we got Candy on deck? Gotta go, gotta go.
[woman] The first AD says that Candy's not coming…
[Barbara] Jesus!
[Paula clears throat]
You were great in that last film you did.
Oh, thanks.
I'm actually an actress myself.
-[actress] Great. -Don't get me wrong,
I love being a stand-in.
Candy and I have been together for years, and she's the best.
It's just that my true passion is acting.
What's your secret to success? If you don't mind me asking.
I guess I believe in boundaries.
Professional boundaries between professionals.
That's probably my whole philosophy.
[coughs nervously]
I was just looking for an acting agent
-and I don't suppose… -Uh, I…
No-- I have to…
Uh…
[Barbara] Louis.
[hushed] Louis, what the actual fuck do you do for your commission?
Well, then get your client out of her trailer and onto this set.
What are you talking about? I love Candy, but I can't wrangle her
while I'm trying to direct this picture with half a crew.
Louis.
What do you want me to do? Want me to call Melissa McCarthy's agent?
[sighs]
Just get her out of the trailer.
[sniffing]
-[knocking] -[sniffs]
[from outside] Candy, it's Louis!
Buddy, Barbara's been giving me a really hard time.
[Louis] You know what? Fuck her, okay?
What do directors even do, right?
They just-- They tell people to do things they were already gonna do
and then take credit for it.
So don't do this film for her, do it for me.
For us?
Huh?
Because I believe in you.
Come on, buddy.
Um, you also owe me money from that movie that you did in Barbados
that you don't remember making.
-What do you say? -[sniffing]
No! Fuck off!
[Louis] And that's a start. So I'm gonna head back to set
and let uh… Barbara know that this went well.
and I'm confident that I will see you momentarily.
Fucking…
Do something.
[knocking]
[Paula] Candy?
[knocking]
Candy, it's Paula, your stand-in.
Listen, I have to tell you something.
I just overheard Barbara saying
they're going to fire you and hire Melissa McCarthy.
Well, good luck to her.
[Paula] Thing is, I don't look anything like Melissa McCarthy.
She'll bring her own stand-in and then I'll be out of a job, so…
[sighs]
[sniffing]
-[sighs] -[Paula] Please come out.
Please.
[Paula] For me?
Okay, everybody. Let's flush this turd down the toilet.
[Barbara] Okay, chop-chop. Let's go!
Picture's up! We're going right for a take.
Everybody, last looks, please.
Okay, come on. Clear the set.
We've been ready. Come on.
We need first team on their marks, please.
Okay. Everybody off the set now.
Can we have a slate in?
[Barbara] Vivian, we can see you. Back off three feet.
Mark it. Thank you.
And…
Action!
I've got the ring right here.
I took it off Grandma's finger while she was dying.
Well, almost dying.
My bitch sister is at a party. She doesn't even know I have it.
-[screams] -[evil laughing]
-[hard thud] -[Candy] Oh!
-Oh my God! -Jesus Christ!
-Cut! -[Candy] What the fuck?
[Barbara] What the hell?
What are you doing? Why didn't you hit her with the bottle?
She really hit her?
-With a fucking marble cat. -[actress] I didn't have breakfast.
Nobody got me breakfast! I'm not myself without breakfast.
Can we get first team some food, please?
-Are you okay? -[panting]
No, Barbara, I'm not fucking okay!
How the fuck would you feel if some stupid bitch
smacked you in the head with a fucking marble cat?
I didn't realize.
[mocking] Oh, didn't realize?
[whines] "Oh, I didn't realize!"
Bullshit!
I should kick your fucking ass!
Here, genius.
Fucking cat, bottle.
Bottle, cat.
One of them is meant to be smashed over a head,
and the other isn't. See?
I'm so sorry.
Don't be fucking sorry. Think!
It's my blood sugar. I didn't have breakfast.
God, you're pathetic. Somebody get her a fucking egg white.
I bet you're on a fucking diet, right?
[Candy] You know how to diet? Eat a fucking pizza and do an 8-ball.
Hey! Fuck you! Don't walk away when I'm fucking talking!
Don't fucking walk away from me when I'm talking to you.
Do I have to do all your jobs for you?
Would that be better?
If I just-- [whines] I helped everyone and none had to fucking do anything.
How about--
Would it be better if I took this bottle
-and smashed it over my own fucking head? -I'll take care of this.
[Candy] Would that be good? It's not funny!
None of this is fucking funny!
And none of you get to fucking laugh unless I'm being funny!
And this, assholes, isn't fucking funny!
Candy, how about we walk?
Louis, get the fuck away from me because, if it wasn't for you,
I wouldn't be doing this crap.
Sorry, Barbara, but this is shit.
[Louis] It's not shit, it's an alternative type of quality.
It is shit! And you're shit, and you're shit,
and you're all fucking shit!
-[glass shatters] -[actress screams]
My eye! Oh my God!
How? It must've been a glass fragment.
-[Barbara] Fuck. -[actress] My God!
-That wasn't my fault. -[Louis] No. It was not.
-I didn't mean to-- -[Louis] I got out of the way, I'm sorry.
I was aiming for him, not her, everybody.
I was-- I just got out of the way.
[pants]
Are you filming this with your phone?
[Candy chuckles]
Are you-- Are you filming this?
Did you send it in already? Is the damage done?
[sobbing]
Louis-- Shit!
Call publicity.
We've got another fucking scandal on our hands.
No. She's fine.
It was an accident.
All you crew members I just talked shit about,
I have an idea.
How about if every one of you
had just a moment of your life
that you didn't want anyone to see, and then it's out there.
Does anyone know what that's like?
Because when you sign up for this fucking job,
you just have to spread them wider and say, "That's right.
I'm on the fucking gynecological table of life.
Look fucking down my goddamn shaft."
Look at it, shine your fucking light in there.
Well, let's walk outside, take a breath.
They'll figure out if she can keep working.
And in the meantime, why don't we talk about…
-anything else? -[sobs]
Shit!
Fuck! Goddamn it!
[screams] Fuck! Fuck! Fuck!
[Jason Kennedy] That infamous incident from five years ago
signaled the end of Candy Black's stellar career.
And today, Hollywood's class clown has fallen to a new low.
Yeah, Ms. Black has been on trial
for six counts of willfully failing to file federal income tax returns
for amounts totaling $6.3 million.
It's been a stunning fall from grace for one
of the most successful female comedy stars of all time.
Of course, beloved by audiences…
[Giuliana Rancic] Candy's career took a nosedive after her on-set meltdown.
[Jason] She's become one of Hollywood's most famous recluses,
hiding out in her Long Island estate, rivaling Howard Hughes and Greta Garbo
for her reluctance to step back into the limelight.
Candy Black did not appear in court today,
and in fact, she has not been seen in public at all for the last five years.
[Jason] Her attorneys claimed she was too drunk to file her taxes,
so a judge has sentenced her to 90 days in rehab.
Coming up next, we have a top mixologist
to show us Candy's shockingly powerful highball whiskey cocktail--
[turns power off]
[dial tone]
[Steve] Hey.
Hey.
Whatcha up to?
[Candy] Watching dumb online news.
That stuff's toxic. It's all noise.
Yeah, I know. You're right.
Getting rid of my TV was the best decision I ever made.
I never watched it, anyway.
And I banned myself from going online till I finish the first draft of my book.
How's the new table coming along?
-You use pine? -[Candy] Fuck pine.
I chose cedar, obviously.
-Did you use a rasp on the legs? -No.
[chuckles] A riffler and some spoon blades.
[deep sigh] I wish I was with you right now.
We could see just how sturdy that table really is.
Yeah. [chuckles]
Me too.
Look, there's something…
I need to talk to you about.
Okay.
Things are just…
They're pretty crazy right now, and…
I might not be able to…
I don't think I'm…
gonna be able to talk to you for a couple months.
I-- A couple of months?
Two or three, at the most.
Wait, why? Where are you going? Why can't we talk on the phone?
I can't tell you,
but, um, after this hiatus,
I just want to pick up right where we left off, and…
I just need you to know
how important this relationship is to me.
What relationship? We've never even met.
Now you're telling me you have to go away and there's nothing you can do about it?
Look, I think that--
Okay, I don't know why you're doing this.
I felt like we were finally getting somewhere, but…
[sighs] Whatever. Anyway, I gotta go.
[sighs]
[car door closes]
[knocking]
Hey, can't sleep in your car around here.
No, of course not. I…
I wasn't sleeping in my car, I…
I just pulled over for a little power nap, that's all.
[policeman] Sure, lady.
Gotta move your car. Street cleaning starts in 10 minutes.
[dial tone]
-[Louis] Hey. -Hey…
Louis. [laughs]
I need a favor.
I was just about to call you.
I was thinking, for the press statement, something akin to…
"I'm ecstatic to have defrauded the federal government
and I'm looking forward to doing enough drugs
to kill Charlie Sheen and his sponsor."
-Whatever. -Buddy, I'm joking.
I don't have to tell you that I don't have to tell you that I'm joking.
Look, I want to go on record here
and let it be known that I know we haven't talked in a bit,
but I'm sorry about the way things ended up with us.
Uh…
You were an asshole. I wasn't at my best and…
that's why we're good together. Let's do more.
-Trilogy Artistic wants you back. -Louis--
Maybe rehab
is a good thing, you know?
It's like a judge-mandated vacation where you come back, lie to the public,
and we go back to fucking them straight in their wallets.
Louis,
listen, I need some contact information.
Okay? Someone I used to work with.
Do you remember my stand-in, Paula…
something?
[phone ringing]
Look, remind the director
the right one blows at the wrist and the left one blows off at the elbow.
Okay.
They're ready for you.
Hi, Terry.
Are there any auditions available today?
Oh, they're auditioning stand-ins now.
I got a few inquiries for background stuff.
Oh, I don't do extra work.
[man] Why? You think you're better than us?
You know, one time, doing a Candy Black vehicle,
and this one, Little Miss Stand-In, doesn't even join us for lunch.
Has no trailer.
Just sits in the corner eating a burrito.
Nice.
-[Terry] Uh, Paula? -What is it?
There's another email here from Louis at Trilogy.
They need someone to play Candy Black in a reenactment.
They want you to go to the producer's house
for an audition.
Right away.
-They want me? -Yeah.
[chuckling] Wow! Oh my God! That's amazing!
Everything's coming up Paula.
[upbeat music playing]
[metal creaks]
Hey.
Oh my God!
[Candy] Sorry, I had to lie to get you to come out here.
[Paula] I didn't recognize you at first.
Well, I stopped going to my colorist
around the same time I stopped looking in the mirror.
And leaving the house.
Come on in.
I guess the stand-in work's kind of dried up.
-Sorry about that. -No problem.
-You want a drink? -Sure.
So, what are you doing for a living these days?
Well, actually, I'm working in a nursing home.
Oh, that must be very rewarding.
Well, it depends on how you feel about cleaning up human shit.
[groans]
It's not bad, actually, but they cut my paycheck,
so I fell behind on my rent and my landlord is kind of a hard-ass
and I lost my apartment, so…
I'm sort of living in my car.
[sighs]
Shit, I'm sorry.
No, don't feel bad for me.
I feel bad for you with that insane verdict.
I know, I didn't get my tax forms in on time.
So fucking what?
The IRS isn't gonna get a new coffee machine?
Exactly, and who cares if you have a drink now and again?
I don't even party anymore.
It's just, I was so messed up for so long, no one cares.
Well, you shouldn't have to go to rehab.
[Candy] Oh, I agree.
But unfortunately, I do.
Unless someone else goes in my place.
How do you mean?
Someone who looks a lot like me.
What?
When I said I had you in mind for a part, I wasn't bullshitting.
I'm the part and you're the only one auditioning.
Think of it like a stand-in job for a rehab movie.
Except there's no cameras and no movie.
[Paula laughs] Oh my God!
Well… [clears throat]
I mean, that would be--
Could be highly illegal.
Technically.
[whispers] Do you actually think we could get away with it?
[chuckles]
No one's seen my face in years, and I could've had work done.
Your face is as good as mine.
I'd do it myself, but there's someone… [inhales]
…there's something…
very important that I have to take care of and…
I'd offer to pay you money, but I'm kind of broke right now.
If I did it, could we go back to the way things were
and I could be your stand-in again?
Hell, no. I'm through with acting.
Why? You are the best.
[scoffs] The best?
At being hit in the face by ladders and watermelons?
You're the queen of comedy. You're Candy Black.
[softly] Not anymore.
[sighs]
I don't want to be an actress,
and I sure as fuck don't want to be famous.
Being famous is like being in the back of a sports car
driven by a bunch of dicks.
My whole career was a mistake.
I got my first acting job
because I was working as a carpenter on some awful comedy.
I was rigging stunt tables, and one day, the lead actress just never showed up.
Turned out she died, an overdose. That should've been a warning.
Anyway, they needed someone to get planked
and I said, "Sure, I'll do it."
Anyway, I'm sick of that shit.
Unlike you. You always loved being on a film set.
Yes, I did.
[sighs]
Listen, I'll do it.
I'll do the rehab thing.
Yeah?
Amazing.
But my price is,
when I get out, you take an acting job,
and make me your stand-in.
Deal?
[gentle electronic music plays]
[softly] Deal.
-[laughs] -Hmm.
[upbeat electronic music]
-[indistinct press chatter] -[cameras clicking]
-[man 1] Candy! -[woman 1] Candy!
[man 2] Candy!
[woman 2] Come on, Candy, give us a picture!
[Candy] So, em…
I don't have to go away, after all.
I'm so relieved.
[Steve] That's amazing. I'm happy we still get to talk.
So, [chuckles]
how's your book coming along?
Ugh…
I've given up trying to write in my apartment.
It's too distracting.
I found this bar around the corner that doesn't have Wi-Fi,
the one bar in Brooklyn not full of hipsters with laptops.
-[Candy] Hmm. -Though I did see one with a typewriter.
[Steve laughs]
[Candy] I can't wait to read it.
I've been reading that Shaker book you recommended.
I just love how self-sufficient they were.
Like…
grow their own food and…
made their own…
buildings and furniture.
That's my dream.
It's just to get off the grid and move to a small town.
Well,
let's just fucking do it, then.
-Yeah? -Yeah.
Have you heard about Pleasant Hill?
It's one of the biggest Shaker settlements.
Uh, well…
We could open up a furniture store and have a cute little apartment above it.
Yeah, and they've got some amazing cedar and maple trees up there.
I'm looking at my Papa Bear chair right now.
Our Papa Bear chair.
Thinking about you,
carving a love seat out of a beautiful piece of cedar.
Your sexy wood talk is giving me wood.
-Oh, really? -[chuckles]
Although we should probably meet face-to-face before we run off together.
[woman] Guys, are we ready to start the meeting?
Candy,
would you like to kick off the sharing?
Would you mind if I didn't?
Perhaps you could tell us about your rock bottom?
Well, I haven't really had a rock bottom,
so maybe someone else in the group who has should share.
Candy, it's important to face the facts
that our disease causes us to make terrible mistakes.
Like that piece of shit movie you made
about the girl who gets super strength when she gets high?
Excuse me, it was called Pippi Bongstocking
and it wasn't shit, it was good.
She got the munchies and she ate a building. It was stupid.
It was a gingerbread house, fucking hilarious.
People, could we bring the focus back to recovery, please?
[therapist] Thank you.
This must be a real wake-up call for you, a big Hollywood hotshot.
Yeah, I've never cleaned a table before. It's a real eye-opener.
Yeah. Everybody's freaking out.
I was like, "You guys, calm down. She's just, like, a lady."
A lady who takes a dump.
Every day.
I might have seen maybe one of your early movies,
but never any of the sequels
and I definitely never read that Vanity Fair profile piece about you.
Um… I didn't wanna mention this in front of everybody,
but I'm Barbara Cox's assistant, the director.
Barbara! Yes, of course.
She's always been very nice to me.
Oh my God, she's the best.
She's actually paying for me to be here now.
Is it because she got sentenced to rehab and you took her place?
What? No, girl. That is crazy.
I kind of had a breakdown a couple weeks ago.
You know what? Here's a tip.
Don't mix Fentanyl, Bennies and heroin.
-Did anyone ever tell you that? -No.
Look, I know you're not supposed to have contact with the outside,
but Barbara messaged me about you.
She wants to know if you're up for doing a cameo
in the Saddle Up reboot.
Really?
Only thing is, is that it films in a couple weeks.
-I feel like you're still gonna be here. -[groans] Shit!
Listen, not a big deal.
Take it from an old pro in the rehab motherfucking game.
If you can convince the ladies with the clipboards
that you are serious about your road to recovery,
they'll send you home early.
Okay, would you tell Barbara I'm up for it,
but I have one condition.
[Ingrid] Girl, name it!
Do you remember my old stand-in?
Oh my God, yes. How can I forget her? She's such a fucking loser.
["Pedestrian At Best" by Courtney Barnett playing]
♪ I love you, I hate you I'm on the fence ♪
♪ It all depends whether I'm up or down ♪
♪ I'm on the mend Transcending all reality ♪
♪ I like you, despise you, admire you ♪
♪ What are we gonna do When everything all falls through? ♪
♪ I must confess I've made a mess Of what should be a small success… ♪
[saw grinding]
♪ This, that, the other Why even bother? ♪
♪ It won't be with me on my deathbed ♪
[deep sigh] Okay,
my name is Candy and I am an alcoholic,
and my story is that I love drinking booze.
I love drinking booze.
In fact, it's my favorite thing to drink.
And, uh, when I've drunk enough booze, I do terrible things like…
falling over or…
I'll drink more and then say terrible things,
like "Get lost," or other things and sometimes I'll pee all over myself,
and other people.
And that's who I am.
I am a booze-loving,
foul-mouthed person
who says and does wrong things and--
And pees on themselves and doesn't always clean it up.
[therapist] Thank you, Candy.
I-- I know that was hard for you. Well done.
Well done.
You've really turned a corner.
Who's ready to share next?
-[indistinct shouting] -[cameras clicking]
You should probably stay until the bottom feeders leave.
[Paula] Really?
That would be amazing.
Sure.
Pick a guest room. I've got, like, 13.
[Paula] So…
the most incredible thing happened at rehab.
You got a job offer, an acting job.
Yeah?
The director Barbara Cox asked for you personally,
and they need a stand-in.
So your comeback starts now.
They want you on set Friday night.
I can't do it.
-What? -I can't do the film.
We had a deal.
I'm not doing the film
because I have something really important that night.
A date.
With who?
A guy, Steve.
And he doesn't know I'm Candy the actress.
Thinks I'm Cathy the carpenter.
-The what? -It's a long story.
I set up a profile on this website for woodworkers,
Carpentry Talk.
It was a nice vacation from…
[deep sigh] …the old movie star missy.
I felt like-- I feel like
I'm more myself as Cathy Tyler, carpenter,
than I ever did as Candy Black, asshole.
Cathy Tyler?
It's my real name.
Louis came up with Candy Black. Anyway, I met Steve on this website.
He's the first guy that's…
ever not seen dollar signs and billboards
before they actually see me.
All we do is talk about furniture.
[sighs] Anyway, we've been talking about meeting up for months,
and Friday night is our anniversary.
Well,
why don't you just tell him the truth?
And then you could reschedule.
Tell him I've been lying to him every day for a year?
I can't do that on our first date.
It probably would make him happy.
It's like buying what you think it's a Ford Focus
and then finding out it's a Maserati.
I can't ruin this relationship so you can get your old job back.
I went to rehab for you. We had a deal.
I know, I'm sorry.
I want my old life back.
Look, I'm sorry. I know this is really shitty, I just--
So…
what is your master plan?
How long are you going to be Cathy the carpenter?
As long as I want.
I mean, don't you want Steve to know who you really are?
Cathy is who I really am.
RIP Candy.
[Candy] Long live Cathy.
[gasps]
[electronic music plays]
[water running]
[blow dryer running]
[buzzer alert]
[buzzer alert]
[buzzer alert]
[electronic beep]
[message alert]
[Paula] Hey.
Wow, you look great.
What's the matter?
It's from Steve.
What does it say?
[Candy] "I'm sorry. I wanted to tell you in person,
but it's simpler this way.
The truth is I'm married and my wife…
[sighs] …found out about us.
Even though I love you, I love…
her more.
I know that doesn't make… sense right now.
I can't see you or speak to you or message you anymore.
She's…
reading all my messages, so please don't try to contact me.
I'm so sorry. It was…
[voice cracking] great getting to know you."
[Paula] Oh, sweetie, that's terrible. I'm so sorry.
At least he bothered to write you
something long and eloquent and beautifully written.
I knew it was too good to be true.
I knew it.
[Paula] Gosh, married this whole time?
And he never mentioned it?
What a lying sack of shit.
Well, maybe work will make you feel better.
[deep sigh]
[crickets chirping]
[phone vibrates]
[phone vibrates]
[phone continues vibrating]
[Paula] Hello?
[Steve] Sorry, I had to call you.
I'm here.
Uh, I know you're scared.
I'm scared too, but if you don't come meet me at this bar,
I'm gonna call you every hour on the hour until you show up.
We have to talk in person tonight.
[gentle electronic music plays]
-[cabbie] Have fun on your date. -It's not a date.
I'm telling someone to get lost.
Cathy?
[Paula] Steve?
You look about as nervous as I feel, I figured it must be you.
[Paula] Hmm.
[nervous laugh] Hi, um…
I made a bet with myself over whether or not you'd make it and…
looks like I lost. Or won, depending on how you look at it.
I hope you're not disappointed that I don't look like a chair.
-No. [chuckles] -Okay.
You look great.
Thanks. You too.
What I can see of you.
Mm-hmm.
[clears throat]
-[giggles] -[Steve] Cathy.
Hello! [giggles]
Do you have a cold?
'Cause your voice… You sound like…
[Paula] No. This is me.
This is the real me.
So…
[sighs]
How's life?
Oh, um, well, I haven't made much progress on my book since last we spoke.
Oh yeah. I get the same way with books. You just lose the thread.
I only got halfway through Gone Girl.
[chuckles]
Good one.
